channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Portugal Eases Limits on Power Imports From Spain After Blackout
item.description: Portugal will continue to ease limits on the electricity interconnection capacity for imports from Spain after trading between the two countries was halted last month due to a blackout.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A traffic light off due to a major blackout in Lisbon, Portugal, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Public transport, traffic lights and phone services were mostly down in parts of Madrid, Barcelona and Lisbon due to the outage, while trains were mostly halted.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Sabic Is Said to Explore IPO of Its Gas Business
item.description: Saudi Arabian chemicals giant Sabic is exploring an initial public offering of its gas business, according to people familiar with the matter, amid a broader operational review.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta, Matthew Martin, Nicolas Parasie

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Euro’s Strength Is Counterintuitive, But Justified
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the recent rise of the euro against the dollar is a consequence of US President Donald Trump’s erratic policies and an opportunity for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Francois De Beaupuy

item.title: Portugal Holds Third Election in Three Years: What to Watch
item.description: Portugal holds its third election in as many years on Sunday, after Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s minority government lost a confidence vote in parliament in March.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal's prime minister, center, at a street rally on May 16. Photographer: Patricia de Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Midpoint of Trump Tariff Hiatus to Reveal Increasingly Unsettled World
item.description: Reports in the coming week may give the fullest reading to date of how major economies are faring with trade disruptions, halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day hiatus on so-called reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn.

item.title: India Restricts Some Imports from Bangladesh as Ties Suffer
item.description: India imposed curbs on imports of ready-made garments and processed food from Bangladesh, as relations between the two neighbors turned sour in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: The land port restrictions may further affect the ties between the two nations as India was Bangladesh’s third-biggest trading partner in 2024.

item.title: Timing Not Right for China Home-Sales Overhaul: State Media
item.description: The timing for a nationwide housing market reform that would only allow developers to sell completed properties is “not mature,” according to China Real Estate Business, an outlet managed by China’s Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng

item.title: New CLO Managers Are Pouring Into the Market
item.description: A spate of hedge funds and asset managers are diving into the $1.3 trillion CLO market with debut vehicles, fueling demand for new leveraged loans and pushing up prices for older ones.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Arroyo, Rachel Graf, Amedeo Goria

item.title: Trump Administration Drops Southwest Scheduling Lawsuit
item.description: The Trump administration dropped a lawsuit against Southwest Airlines Co. that accused the airline of setting unrealistic flight schedules that led to chronic delays.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

media:content.media:description: A ramp agents walks under the wing of a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737-700 airplane as it is pushed back from the gate for departure at Baltimore-Washington Airport (BWI) in Baltimore, Maryland, US, on Friday, April 12, 2024. Southwest Airlines Co. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 25.

item.title: NJ Transit CEO Speaks Before Meeting Union Amid Strike
item.description: NJ Transit CEO Kris Kolluri held a presser before meeting with union on Saturday. He a said he appreciates their contribution to the agency and that his objective is to "make sure they get back to work." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sweden as Europe's Bright Spot for Capital Markets
item.description: How has a nation of 10 million people built one of the most dynamic capital markets in Europe? Adena Friedman speaks with us from Stockholm on Nasdaq’s presence in the Nordic country. Sweden's minister for financial markets Niklas Wykman, Investor AB CEO Christian Cederholm, Froda CEO Olle Lundin and Swedbank CEO Jens Henriksson talk about the country's combination of social welfare and business-friendly policies that encourage risk-taking and deepen its capital markets at a time when the rest of the EU struggles to innovate and grow. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Who Has the Upper Hand in US-China Relations?
item.description: Former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and Hoover Institution Senior Fellow Elizabeth Economy discuss the US pivot on trade dealings with China. Summers believes there’s pressure on the Chinese economy, but believes that there’s even more pressure on the US economy. Elizabeth Economy states that both the US and China have “economic vulnerabilities.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Turkey Makes $30 Billion Natural Gas Discovery in the Black Sea
item.description: Turkey has discovered 75 billion cubic meters of natural gas worth $30 billion dollars in the Black Sea, according to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: Inci Ozbek

media:content.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey's president, during a news conference at Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome, at Villa Doria Pamphili in Roma, Italy, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Erdogan travelled to Italy to meet with Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and attend a business forum in Rome.

item.title: Innovation for Growth in Sweden and for US National Defense
item.description: Sweden and the US Defense Department are both undergoing changes.
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: Adena Friedman, chief executive officer of Nasdaq Inc., at the Semafor World Economy Summit during the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Spring meetings in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The International Monetary Fund sharply lowered its forecasts for world growth for this year and next, warning the outlook could deteriorate further as US President Donald Trump's tariffs spark a global trade war.

item.title: Grim Economic Outlook Overtakes Solid Earnings as Tariff Disruptions Surface
item.description: One thing is clear as the first-quarter earnings season draws to a close: The uncertain outlook for the global economy is superseding better-than-feared results even as stocks rally on signs of easing trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey, Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: Sales associates work in the parts department as John Deere agricultural sprayers sit outside the window at Klein Equipment, a John Deere dealership, in Galesburg, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 12, 2013. Deere & Co., the world's largest maker of agricultural equipment, is scheduled to release quarterly earnings on Feb. 13.

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says ‘Steady Hand’ Needed on Interest Rates
item.description: The European Central Bank should remain cautious on interest-rate moves, according to Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Isabel Schnabel, executive board member of the European Central Bank, during an interview at the ECB in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, Nov. 25, 2024. “Given the inflation outlook, I think we can gradually move toward neutral if the incoming data continue to confirm our baseline,” Schnabel said.

item.title: China Drops to No. 3 Holder of Treasuries, Behind UK
item.description: China shrank its holdings of US Treasuries in March, with the UK replacing it as the No. 2 overseas owner.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: US Loses Last Top Credit Rating With Downgrade From Moody’s
item.description: The US was stripped of its last top credit rating by Moody’s Ratings, reflecting deepening concern that ballooning debt and deficits will damage America’s standing as the preeminent destination for global capital and increase the government’s borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Fire at Kumho Tire’s Gwangju Plant in Korea Halts Production
item.description: A fire broke out at Kumho Tire’s plant in Gwangju at around 7:11am Saturday, forcing the company to halt production, according to Yonhap News Agency.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Developing News slate for BTDY, BTODAY, WKND, Weekend and Today 24/7 teams. Can be used in main story, large photo slots and also Sidebars and ICYMI square thumbnails. See also Breaking News slate.

item.title: Turkey’s Celebi Says It’s Cooperating After India Revokes Clearance
item.description: Turkish company Çelebi Aviation said on Saturday it’s “fully cooperating” with Indian authorities and adhering to regulations after its ground handling and cargo warehouse operations were suspended due to national security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Boarding stairs stand on the tarmac at Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport, operated by Adani Group, in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, May 22, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, the conglomerate controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc. Photographer: Sumit Dayal/Bloomberg

item.title: AirTrunk Billionaire Buys Second Property in Sydney’s Crown: SMH
item.description: Founder and chief executive of Australian data center operator AirTrunk Robin Khuda and his wife Melea bought a second property in Sydney’s Crown Towers for roughly A$20 million ($12.8 million), the Sydney Morning Herald reported Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: View of the Sydney Opera House from the penthouse at One Barangaroo Crown residences in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. The apartment is perched atop One Barangaroo tower, which won the global Emporis Skyscraper Award in 2020 in a first by an Australian structure. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Stocks Fall Late on US Downgrade as Yields Climb: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks dropped in late hours and bond yields climbed after the US was downgraded by Moody’s Ratings amid concerns about the increase in government debt that threatens America’s status as the world’s safe haven.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Wall Street Strategists React to Moody’s US Credit Rating Cut
item.description: US stocks declined and Treasury yields rose after Moody’s Ratings downgraded the US credit rating, citing an increase in government debt and a higher interest burden.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Carmen Reinicke, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Indian Companies, Consumers Snub Pakistan and Its Allies
item.description: A growing number of Indian merchants, companies, and consumers are cutting business ties with Pakistan and some of its allies after a heightened conflict between the South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: Activists protest against Turkey in New Delhi on May 16.

item.title: China Pivot, Sweden's Innovation Engine, US Army Secretary Driscoll | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and Hoover Institution's Elizabeth Economy discuss the US pivot on trade dealings with China. Plus, a look at Sweden’s vibrant capital markets and Nasdaq's role in its innovation ecosystem. Later, US Army Secretary Driscoll joins us with the administration's approach to a decades-long spending challenge at the Pentagon. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Lutnick-Built FMX to Start Treasury Futures Trade in Blow to CME
item.description: An exchange founded by Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick is set to start the long-awaited trading of US Treasury futures next week in a blow to CME Group Inc., which dominates that market.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder, Edward Bolingbroke

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick, US commerce secretary, prior to a Fox Business television interview outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. US President Donald Trump on Thursday announced a trade framework with the UK, hailing it as a "breakthrough" that will bring down barriers and expand market access for American imports.

item.title: Equities Climb Despite Inflation Angst | Bloomberg: The Close 05/16/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are BMO Private Wealth Chief Market Strategist Carol Schleif, JPMorgan US Inflation Strategy Head Phoebe White, Seaport Research Partners Senior Analyst David Joyce, Bogg Bag Founder and CEO Kim Vaccarella, American Century Investments Multi-Asset Strategies CIO Richard Weiss, 22V Research Washington Policy Research Head Kim Wallace, PWC CTIO Matt Wood, WSL Strategic Retail CEO and Chief Shopper Wendy Liebmann, JLL Retail Advisory Services President Naveen Jaggi, Glowbar CEO and Founder Rachel Liverman (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mehvish Ayub on Trade War, Trump Administration, China Stocks
item.description: Mehvish Ayub Bank of Singapore Executive Director of Investment Solutions Mehvish Ayub discusses the trade war between China and US, the Trump administration's handling of financial markets, and Chinese stocks. She speaks with Joumanna Bercetche on "Bloomberg Horizons Middle East and Africa." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Space, Defense Firm Voyager Technologies Files Publicly for IPO
item.description: Voyager Technologies Inc. filed publicly for an initial public offering, as it seeks to capitalize on rising government spending on advanced defense technologies and space exploration.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. Signs Donald Trump is rethinking the most-aggressive elements of his combative stances on trade and the Federal Reserve sent stocks to the first back-to-back gains since his tariff war escalated, while soothing volatility across asset classes. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Monica Defend on US Dollar, Fed Cuts, Gold
item.description: Amundi Investment Institute Head Monica Defend discusses how they were surprised with the US Dollar as it correlated with the equity market. In an interview with Francine Lacqua she says she believes the fed will make three cuts this year, they're staying neutral on China, and overweight in gold. (Source: Bloomberg)
